Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Thank you.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Thank you so much.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Thank you.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Thank you all so so much.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Thank you.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Thank you.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Thank you all very, very much.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Thank you for that amazing welcome.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Thank you all for the great convention that we've had.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And Chelsea, thank you.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I'm so proud to be your mother and so proud of the woman you've become.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Thank you for bringing Marc into our family, and Charlotte and Aidan into the world.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And Bill, that conversation we started in the law library 45 years ago, it is still going strong.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You know, that conversation has lasted through good times that filled us with joy, and hard times that tested us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I've even gotten a few words in along the way.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: On Tuesday night, I was so happy to see that my explainer-in-chief is still on the job.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I'm also grateful to the rest of my family and to the friends of a lifetime.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: For all of you whose hard work brought us here tonight, and to those of you who joined this campaign this week.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Thank you.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: What a remarkable week it's been.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We heard the man from Hope, Bill Clinton.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And the man of Hope, Barack Obama.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: America is stronger because of President Obama's leadership, and I'm better because of his friendship.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We heard from our terrific vice president, the one and only Joe Biden.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He spoke from his big heart about our party's commitment to working people, as only he can do.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And first lady Michelle Obama reminded us that our children are watching, and the president we elect is going to be their president, too.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And for those of you out there who are just getting to know Tim Kaine — you will soon understand why the people of Virginia keep promoting him: from city council and mayor, to governor, and now senator.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And he will make the whole country proud as our vice president.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And ... I want to thank Bernie Sanders.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Bernie, Bernie, your campaign inspired millions of Americans, particularly the young people who threw their hearts and souls into our primary.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You've put economic and social justice issues front and center, where they belong.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And to all of your supporters here and around the country: I want you to know, I've heard you.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Your cause is our cause.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Our country needs your ideas, energy and passion.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That is the only way we can turn our progressive platform into real change for America.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We wrote it together — now let's go out and make it happen together.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: My friends, we've come to Philadelphia — the birthplace of our nation — because what happened in this city 240 years ago still has something to teach us today.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We all know the story.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But we usually focus on how it turned out — and not enough on how close that story came to never being written at all.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: When representatives from 13 unruly colonies met just down the road from here, some wanted to stick with the king.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And some wanted to stick it to the king.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: The revolution hung in the balance.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Then somehow, they began listening to each other, compromising, finding common purpose.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And by the time they left Philadelphia, they had begun to see themselves as one nation.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's what made it possible to stand up to a king.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That took courage.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: They had courage.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Our Founders embraced the enduring truth that we are stronger together.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Now, now America is once again at a moment of reckoning.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Powerful forces are threatening to pull us apart.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Bonds of trust and respect are fraying.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And just as with our founders, there are no guarantees.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It truly is up to us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We have to decide whether we all will work together so we can all rise together.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Our country's motto is "e pluribus unum": out of many, we are one.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Will we stay true to that motto?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, we heard Donald Trump's answer last week at his convention.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He wants to divide us from the rest of the world, and from each other.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He's betting that the perils of today's world will blind us to its unlimited promise.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He's taken the Republican Party a long way from "Morning in America" to "Midnight in America."

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He wants us to fear the future and fear each other.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, you know, a great Democratic President Franklin Delano Roosevelt came up with the perfect rebuke to Trump more than 80 years ago, during a much more perilous time: "The only thing we have to fear is fear itself."

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Now we are clear-eyed about what our country is up against.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But we are not afraid.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We will rise to the challenge, just as we always have.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We will not build a wall.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Instead, we will build an economy where everyone who wants a good job can get one.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And we'll build a path to citizenship for millions of immigrants who are already contributing to our economy!

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We, we will not ban a religion.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We will work with all Americans and our allies to fight and defeat terrorism.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: There's a lot of work to do.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Too many people haven't had a pay raise since the crash.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: There's too much inequality.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Too little social mobility.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Too much paralysis in Washington.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Too many threats at home and abroad.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But just look for a minute at the strengths we bring as Americans to meet these challenges.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We have the most dynamic and diverse people in the world.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We have the most tolerant and generous young people we've ever had.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We have the most powerful military.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: The most innovative entrepreneurs.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: The most enduring values: freedom and equality, justice and opportunity.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We should be so proud that those words are associated with us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I have to tell you, as your secretary of state, I went to 112 countries.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: When people hear those words, they hear America.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So don't let anyone tell you that our country is weak.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We're not.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Don't let anyone tell you we don't have what it takes.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We do.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And most of all, don't believe anyone who says, "I alone can fix it."

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Yes, those were actually Donald Trump's words in Cleveland.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And they should set off alarm bells for all of us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Really?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I alone can fix it?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Isn't he forgetting?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Troops on the front lines.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Police officers and firefighters who run toward danger.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Doctors and nurses who care for us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Teachers who change lives.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Entrepreneurs who see possibilities in every problem.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Mothers who lost children to violence and are building a movement to keep other kids safe.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He's forgetting every last one of us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Americans don't say, "I alone can fix it." We say, "We'll fix it together."

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And remember, remember: Our Founders fought a revolution and wrote a Constitution so America would never be a nation where one person had all the power.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Two-hundred-and-forty years later, we still put our faith in each other.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Look at what happened in Dallas after the assassinations of five brave police officers.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Police Chief David Brown asked the community to support his force, maybe even join them.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And you know how the community responded?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Nearly 500 people applied in just 12 days.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's how Americans answer when the call for help goes out.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Twenty years ago, I wrote a book called It Takes a Village.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And a lot of people looked at the title and asked, "What the heck do you mean by that?"

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: This is what I mean.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: None of us can raise a family, build a business, heal a community or lift a country totally alone.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: America needs every one of us to lend our energy, our talents, our ambition to making our nation better and stronger.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I believe that with all my heart.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's why "Stronger Together" is not just a lesson from our history.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It's not just a slogan for our campaign.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It's a guiding principle for the country we've always been and the future we're going to build.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: A country where the economy works for everyone, not just those at the top.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Where you can get a good job and send your kids to a good school, no matter what zip code you live in.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: A country where all our children can dream, and those dreams are within reach.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Where families are strong, communities are safe, and yes, where love trumps hate.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's the country we're fighting for.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's the future we're working toward.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And so, my friends, it is with humility, determination and boundless confidence in America's promise that I accept your nomination for president of the United States!

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Now, sometimes, sometimes the people at this podium are new to the national stage.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: As you know, I'm not one of those people.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I've been your First Lady, served eight years as a senator from the great state of New York.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Then I represented all of you as secretary of state.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But my job titles only tell you what I've done.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: They don't tell you why.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: The truth is, through all these years of public service, the "service" part has always come easier to me than the "public" part.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I get it that some people just don't know what to make of me.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So let me tell you.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: The family I'm from, well, no one had their name on big buildings.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: My family were builders of a different kind.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Builders in the way most American families are.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: They used whatever tools they had — whatever God gave them — and whatever life in America provided — and built better lives and better futures for their kids.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: My grandfather worked in the same Scranton lace mill for 50 years.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Because he believed that if he gave everything he had, his children would have a better life than he did.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And he was right.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: My dad, Hugh, made it to college.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He played football at Penn State and enlisted in the Navy after Pearl Harbor.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: When the war was over, he started his own small business, printing fabric for draperies.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I remember watching him stand for hours over silk screens.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He wanted to give my brothers and me opportunities he never had.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And he did.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: My mother, Dorothy, was abandoned by her parents as a young girl.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: She ended up on her own at 14, working as a housemaid.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: She was saved by the kindness of others.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Her first-grade teacher saw she had nothing to eat at lunch and brought extra food to share the entire year.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: The lesson she passed on to me, years later, stuck with me: No one gets through life alone.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We have to look out for each other and lift each other up.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And she made sure I learned the words from our Methodist faith: "Do all the good you can, for all the people you can, in all the ways you can, as long as ever you can."

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So, I went to work for the Children's Defense Fund, going door-to-door in New Bedford, Mass., on behalf of children with disabilities who were denied the chance to go to school.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I remember meeting a young girl in a wheelchair on the small back porch of her house.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: She told me how badly she wanted to go to school — it just didn't seem possible in those days.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I couldn't stop thinking of my mother and what she'd gone through as a child.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It became clear to me that simply caring is not enough.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: To drive real progress, you have to change both hearts and laws.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You need both understanding and action.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So we gathered facts.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We built a coalition.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And our work helped convince Congress to ensure access to education for all students with disabilities.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It's a big idea, isn't it?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Every kid with a disability has the right to go to school.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But how, how do you make an idea like that real?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You do it step-by-step, year-by-year, sometimes even door-by-door.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: My heart just swelled when I saw Anastasia Somoza representing millions of young people on this stage — because we changed our law to make sure she got an education.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So it's true.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I sweat the details of policy — whether we're talking about the exact level of lead in the drinking water in Flint, Mich., the number of mental health facilities in Iowa, or the cost of your prescription drugs.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Because it's not just a detail if it's your kid — if it's your family.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It's a big deal.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And it should be a big deal to your president, too.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: After the four days of this convention, you've seen some of the people who've inspired me.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: People who let me into their lives, and became a part of mine.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: People like Ryan Moore and Lauren Manning.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: They told their stories Tuesday night.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I first met Ryan as a 7-year-old.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He was wearing a full body brace that must have weighed 40 pounds, because I leaned over to lift him up.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Children like Ryan kept me going when our plan for universal health care failed and kept me working with leaders of both parties to help create the Children's Health Insurance Program that covers 8 million kids in our country.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Lauren Manning, who stood here with such grace and power, was gravely injured on 9/11.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It was the thought of her, and Debbie St. John who you saw in the movie, and John Dolan and Joe Sweeney, and all the victims and survivors, that kept me working as hard as I could in the Senate on behalf of 9/11 families, and our first responders who got sick from their time at Ground Zero.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I was thinking of Lauren, Debbie and all the others 10 years later in the White House Situation Room when President Obama made the courageous decision that finally brought Osama bin Laden to justice.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And in this campaign, I've met many more people who motivate me to keep fighting for change.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And, with your help, I will carry all of your voices and stories with me to the White House.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And you heard, you heard from, from Republicans and Independents who are supporting our campaign.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, I will be a president for Democrats, Republicans and independents, for the struggling, the striving, the successful, for all those who vote for me and for those who don't.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: For all Americans together.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Tonight, tonight we've reached a milestone in our nation's march toward a more perfect union: the first time that a major party has nominated a woman for president.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Standing here, standing here as my mother's daughter, and my daughter's mother, I'm so happy this day has come.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I'm happy for grandmothers and little girls and everyone in between.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I'm happy for boys and men, too — because when any barrier falls in America, it clears the way for everyone.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: After all, when there are no ceilings, the sky's the limit.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So let's keep going, let's keep going until every one of the 161 million women and girls across America has the opportunity she deserves to have.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But even more important than the history we make tonight, is the history we will write together in the years ahead.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Let's begin with what we're going to do to help working people in our country get ahead and stay ahead.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Now, I don't think President Obama and Vice President Biden get the credit they deserve for saving us from the worst economic crisis of our lifetimes.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Our economy is so much stronger than when they took office.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Nearly 15 million new private-sector jobs.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Twenty million more Americans with health insurance.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And an auto industry that just had its best year ever.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Now that's real progress, but none of us can be satisfied with the status quo.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Not by a long shot.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We're still facing deep-seated problems that developed long before the recession and have stayed with us through the recovery.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I've gone around our country talking to working families.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I've heard from many who feel like the economy sure isn't working for them.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Some of you are frustrated — even furious.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And you know what?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You're right.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It's not yet working the way it should.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Americans are willing to work — and work hard.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But right now, an awful lot of people feel there is less and less respect for the work they do.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And less respect for them, period.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Democrats, we are the party of working people.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But we haven't done a good enough job showing we get what you're going through, and we're going to do something to help.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So tonight I want to tell you tonight how we will empower Americans to live better lives.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: My primary mission as president will be to create more opportunity and more good jobs with rising wages right here in the United States.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: From my first day in office to my last, especially in places that for too long have been left out and left behind.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: From our inner cities to our small towns, from Indian Country to Coal Country.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: From communities ravaged by addiction to regions hollowed out by plant closures.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And here's what I believe.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I believe America thrives when the middle class thrives.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I believe that our economy isn't working the way it should because our democracy isn't working the way it should.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's why we need to appoint Supreme Court justices who will get money out of politics and expand voting rights, not restrict them.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And if necessary, we will pass a constitutional amendment to overturn Citizens United.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I believe American corporations that have gotten so much from our country should be just as patriotic in return.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Many of them are.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But too many aren't.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It's wrong to take tax breaks with one hand and give out pink slips with the other.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I believe Wall Street can never, ever be allowed to wreck Main Street again.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I believe in science.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I believe climate change is real and that we can save our planet while creating millions of good-paying clean energy jobs.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I believe that when we have millions of hardworking immigrants contributing to our economy, it would be self-defeating and inhumane to try to kick them out.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Comprehensive immigration reform will grow our economy and keep families together — and it's the right thing to do.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So, whatever party you belong to, or if you belong to no party at all, if you share these beliefs, this is your campaign.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: If you believe that companies should share profits with their workers, not pad executive bonuses, join us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: If you believe the minimum wage should be a living wage, and no one working full time should have to raise their children in poverty, join us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: If you believe that every man, woman and child in America has the right to affordable health care, join us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: If you believe that we should say "no" to unfair trade deals, that we should stand up to China, that we should support our steelworkers and autoworkers and homegrown manufacturers, then join us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: If you believe we should expand Social Security and protect a woman's right to make her own health care decisions, then join us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And yes, yes, if you believe that your working mother, wife, sister or daughter deserves equal pay, join us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's how we're going to sure this economy works for everyone, not just those at the top.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Now, you didn't hear any of this, did you, from Donald Trump at his convention.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He spoke for 70-odd minutes — and I do mean odd.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And he offered zero solutions.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But we already know he doesn't believe these things.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: No wonder he doesn't like talking about his plans.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You might have noticed, I love talking about mine.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: In my first hundred days, we will work with both parties to pass the biggest investment in new, good-paying jobs since World War II.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Jobs in manufacturing, clean energy, technology and innovation, small business, and infrastructure.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: If we invest in infrastructure now, we'll not only create jobs today, but lay the foundation for the jobs of the future.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And we will also transform the way we prepare our young people for those jobs.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Bernie Sanders and I will work together to make college tuition-free for the middle class and debt-free for all!

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We will also, we will also liberate millions of people who already have student debt.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It's just not right that Donald Trump can ignore his debts, and students and families can't refinance their debts.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And something we don't say often enough: Sure, college is crucial, but a four-year degree should not be the only path to a good job.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We will help more people learn a skill or practice a trade and make a good living doing it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We will give small businesses like my dad's a boost.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Make it easier to get credit.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Way too many dreams die in the parking lots of banks.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: In America, if you can dream it, you should be able to build it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And we will help you balance family and work.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And you know what, if fighting for affordable child care and paid family leave is playing the "woman card," then deal me in.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Now, here's the other thing, we're not only going to make all these investments, we're going to pay for every single one of them.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And here's how: Wall Street, corporations, and the super-rich are going to start paying their fair share of taxes.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: This is not because we resent success, because when more than 90 percent of the gains have gone to the top 1 percent, that's where the money is, and we are going to follow the money.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And if companies take tax breaks and then ship jobs overseas, we'll make them pay us back.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And we'll put that money to work where it belongs, creating jobs here at home!

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Now, now I imagine some of you are sitting at home thinking, well, that all sounds pretty good.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But how are you going to get it done?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: How are you going to break through the gridlock in Washington?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, look at my record.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I've worked across the aisle to pass laws and treaties and to launch new programs that help millions of people.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And if you give me the chance, that's what I'll do as president.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But then I also imagine people are thinking out there, but Trump, he's a businessman.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He must know something about the economy.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, let's take a closer look.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: In Atlantic City, 60 miles from here, you will find contractors and small businesses who lost everything because Donald Trump refused to pay his bills.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Now, remember what the president said last night: "Don't boo, vote."

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: People who did the work and needed the money, and didn't get it — not because he couldn't pay them, but because he wouldn't pay them.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He just stiffed them.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And you know that sales pitch he's making to be president?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Put your faith in him — and you'll win big?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's the same sales pitch he made to all those small businesses.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Then Trump walked away, and left working people holding the bag.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He also talks a big game about putting America first.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, please explain what part of "America First" leads him to make Trump ties in China, not Colorado.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Trump suits in Mexico, not Michigan.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Trump furniture in Turkey, not Ohio.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Trump picture frames in India, not Wisconsin.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Donald Trump says he wants to make America great again — well, he could start by actually making things in America again.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Now, the choice we face in this election is just as stark when it comes to our national security.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You know, anyone, anyone reading the news can see the threats and turbulence we face.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: From Baghdad to Kabul, to Nice and Paris and Brussels, from San Bernardino to Orlando, we're dealing with determined enemies that must be defeated.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So, it's no wonder that people are anxious and looking for reassurance.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Looking for steady leadership, wanting a leader who understands we are stronger when we work with our allies around the world and care for our veterans here at home.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Keeping our nation safe and honoring the people who do that work will be my highest priority.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I'm proud that we put a lid on Iran's nuclear program without firing a single shot — now we have to enforce it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And we must keep supporting Israel's security.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I'm proud that we shaped a global climate agreement — now we have to hold every country accountable to their commitments, including ourselves.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I'm proud to stand by our allies in NATO against any threat they face, including from Russia.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I've laid out my strategy for defeating ISIS.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We will strike their sanctuaries from the air, and support local forces taking them out on the ground.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We will surge our intelligence so that we detect and prevent attacks before they happen.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We will disrupt their efforts online to reach and radicalize young people in our country.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It won't be easy or quick, but make no mistake — we will prevail.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Now Donald Trump, Donald Trump says, and this is a quote, "I know more about ISIS than the generals do."

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: No, Donald, you don't.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He thinks, he thinks that he knows more than our military because he claimed our armed forces are "a disaster."

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, I've had the privilege to work closely with our troops and our veterans for many years, including as a senator on the Armed Services Committee, and I know how wrong he is.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Our military is a national treasure.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We entrust our commander in chief to make the hardest decisions our nation faces, decisions about war and peace, life and death.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: A president should respect the men and women who risk their lives to serve our country — including Captain Khan and the sons of Tim Kaine and Mike Pence, both Marines.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So just ask yourself: Do you really think Donald Trump has the temperament to be commander in chief?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Donald Trump can't even handle the rough-and-tumble of a presidential campaign.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He loses his cool at the slightest provocation.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: When he's gotten a tough question from a reporter.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: When he's challenged in a debate.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: When he sees a protester at a rally.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Imagine, if you dare, imagine, imagine him in the Oval Office facing a real crisis.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: A man you can bait with a tweet is not a man we can trust with nuclear weapons.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I can't put it, I can't put it any better than Jackie Kennedy did after the Cuban Missile Crisis.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: She said that what worried President Kennedy during that very dangerous time was that a war might be started, not by big men with self-control and restraint, but by little men — the ones moved by fear and pride.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: America's strength doesn't come from lashing out.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It relies on smarts, judgment, cool resolve, and the precise and strategic application of power.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And that's the kind of commander in chief I pledge to be.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And if we're serious about keeping our country safe, we also can't afford to have a president who's in the pocket of the gun lobby.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I'm not here to repeal the Second Amendment.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I'm not here to take away your guns.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I just don't want you to be shot by someone who shouldn't have a gun in the first place.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We will work tirelessly with responsible gun owners to pass common-sense reforms and keep guns out of the hands of criminals, terrorists and all others who would do us harm.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You know, for decades, people have said this issue was too hard to solve and the politics too hot to touch.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But I ask you: How can we just stand by and do nothing?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You heard, you saw, family members of people killed by gun violence on this stage.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You heard, you saw, family members of police officers killed in the line of duty because they were outgunned by criminals.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I refuse to believe we can't find common ground here.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We have to heal the divides in our country.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Not just on guns.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But on race.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Immigration.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And more.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And that starts with listening, listening to each other.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Trying, as best we can, to walk in each other's shoes.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So let's put ourselves in the shoes of young black and Latino men and women who face the effects of systemic racism, and are made to feel like their lives are disposable.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Let's put ourselves in the shoes of police officers, kissing their kids and spouses goodbye every day, heading off to do a dangerous and necessary job.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We will reform our criminal justice system from end to end and rebuild trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And we will defend, we will defend all our rights — civil rights, human rights and voting rights, women's rights and workers' rights, LGBT rights and the rights of people with disabilities!

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And we will stand up against mean and divisive rhetoric wherever it comes from.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You know, for the past year, many people made the mistake of laughing off Donald Trump's comments — excusing him as an entertainer just putting on a show.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: They thought he couldn't possibly mean all the horrible things he says — like when he called women "pigs."

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Or said that an American judge couldn't be fair because of his Mexican heritage.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Or when he mocks and mimics a reporter with a disability.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Or insults prisoners of war like John McCain — a true hero and patriot who deserves our respect.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Now, at first, at first, I admit, I couldn't believe he meant it either.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It was just too hard to fathom — that someone who wants to lead our nation could say those things.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Could be like that.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But here's the sad truth: There is no other Donald Trump.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: This is it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And in the end, it comes down to what Donald Trump doesn't get: that America is great — because America is good.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So enough with the bigotry and bombast.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Donald Trump's not offering real change.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He's offering empty promises.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And what are we offering?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: A bold agenda to improve the lives of people across our country — to keep you safe, to get you good jobs, and to give your kids the opportunities they deserve.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: The choice is clear, my friends.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Every generation of Americans has come together to make our country freer, fairer and stronger.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: None of us ever have or can do it alone.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I know that at a time when so much seems to be pulling us apart, it can be hard to imagine how we'll ever pull together.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But I'm here to tell you tonight — progress is possible.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I know, I know because I've seen it in the lives of people across America who get knocked down and get right back up.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I know it, I know it from my own life.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: More than a few times, I've had to pick myself up and get back in the game.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Like so much else in my life, I got this from my mother too.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: She never let me back down from any challenge.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: When I tried to hide from a neighborhood bully, she literally blocked the door."

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Go back out there," she said.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And she was right.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You have to stand up to bullies.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You have to keep working to make things better, even when the odds are long and the opposition is fierce.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We lost our mother a few years ago, but I miss her every day.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I still hear her voice urging me to keep working, keep fighting for right, no matter what.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's what we need to do together as a nation.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Though "we may not live to see the glory," as the song from the musical Hamilton goes, "let us gladly join the fight."

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Let our legacy be about "planting seeds in a garden you never get to see."

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's why we're here ... not just in this hall, but on this Earth.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: The Founders showed us that.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And so have many others since.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: They were drawn together by love of country, and the selfless passion to build something better for all who follow.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That is the story of America.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And we begin a new chapter tonight.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Yes, the world is watching what we do.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Yes, America's destiny is ours to choose.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So let's be stronger together, my fellow Americans.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Let's look to the future with courage and confidence.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Let's build a better tomorrow for our beloved children and our beloved country.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And when we do, America will be greater than ever.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Thank you, and may God bless you and the United States of America!
